reviewText:
Today's generation has really lost touch with what makes for a genuine puzzle. You don't need flashy colors, or pretty music to make a quality puzzle game. You just need a unique idea, and unique mechanics.

I remember the days when people were playing preinstalled puzzle games like Minesweeper on their computers. Sure, it was simple, and looking back now it actually seems kind of boring, but at the time we had a lot of fun doing it! We were always trying to beat each others scores and engaging in a mostly healthy rivalry over it.

Spectrubes is no different. The game doesn't really teach you how to play (aside from basic instructions), but you're expected to figure it out the mechanics for yourself. It counts how many moves you make, and I believe it spans roughly 100 levels. The difficulty curve is a little high, but this makes for unique and challenging gameplay! This isn't the greatest puzzle game I've ever played as it does get a little boring with time, nor is it a game for everybody. However, its unique mechanics and minimalist style give the game a certain allurement that both 80's kids and/or puzzle enthusiasts can appreciate!
